articles.headline: India’s Central Bank Chief May Have a Short Honeymoon
articles.snippet: Glowing coverage of Raghuram Rajan, the new governor of the Reserve Bank of India, could be quickly eclipsed by escalating economic troubles.
articles.abstract: Glowing coverage of Raghuram Rajan, the new governor of the Reserve Bank of India, could be quickly eclipsed by escalating economic troubles.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Indian newspapers have been gushing about the new governor of the central bank, Raghuram Rajan, in terms usually reserved for Bollywood film stars: his trim physique, his long-distance running, even his “rather photogenic appeal,” as The Mumbai Mirror tabloid wrote this week.

articles.headline: On the Edge of Poverty, at the Center of a Debate on Food Stamps
articles.snippet: As lawmakers cast a fight over cuts to food stamps in terms of spending, budget analysts and hunger relief advocates warn of a spike in “food insecurity” among Americans.
articles.abstract: As lawmakers cast a fight over cuts to food stamps in terms of spending, budget analysts and hunger relief advocates warn of a spike in “food insecurity” among Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: DYERSBURG, Tenn. — As a self-described “true Southern man” — and reluctant recipient of food stamps — Dustin Rigsby, a struggling mechanic, hunts deer, doves and squirrels to help feed his family. He shops for grocery bargains, cooks budget-stretching stews and limits himself to one meal a day.

articles.headline: Auto Sales Are Soaring, Propelled by Leases
articles.snippet: General Motors, Ford and Chrysler all had strong months as lower lease payments helped dealers move the inventory of new cars and trucks.
articles.abstract: General Motors, Ford and Chrysler all had strong months as lower lease payments helped dealers move the inventory of new cars and trucks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Automakers have traditionally used the lease as a way of making high-end cars and trucks more accessible for consumers who could not afford the full sticker price. But today, with credit more available and consumer confidence increasing, automakers are extending the strategy to more moderately priced cars, which in turn is helping bring about surprisingly strong sales results.

articles.headline: No Strings on a Piano, but the Tone Is Grand
articles.snippet: To its line of hybrid grand and upright pianos, Yamaha adds the NU1 — more compact and less expensive, but with real piano sound, not digital noise.
articles.abstract: To its line of hybrid grand and upright pianos, Yamaha adds the NU1 — more compact and less expensive, but with real piano sound, not digital noise.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are some things you just don’t expect to read about in a column about electronics. Gluten-free waffles, for example. Ferrets. Moist towelettes.

articles.headline: Opponents of Summers Must Overcome His Bond With Obama
articles.snippet: Decision time is here, and while President Obama has not settled on who should take over the Federal Reserve, he still favors Lawrence Summers.
articles.abstract: Decision time is here, and while President Obama has not settled on who should take over the Federal Reserve, he still favors Lawrence Summers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama turned to second-term job openings soon after his re-election, the topic one day in the Oval Office was probably the most important economic decision he would make: Who should succeed the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, after 2013?

articles.headline: Falling Economic Tide in India Is Exposing Its Chronic Troubles
articles.snippet: As its boom ends, India suffers from a weak currency, soaring prices, neglected infrastructure and red tape.
articles.abstract: As its boom ends, India suffers from a weak currency, soaring prices, neglected infrastructure and red tape.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — India had seemed tantalizingly close to embarking on the same dash for economic growth that has lifted hundreds of millions of people out of poverty in China and across East Asia.

articles.headline: Obama Faces Barrier in His Own Party on Syria
articles.snippet: Democrats say they are confronted with a difficult choice: go against the wishes of President Obama or defy voters who are overwhelmingly opposed to involving the United States in another unpredictable Middle East war.
articles.abstract: Democrats say they are confronted with a difficult choice: go against the wishes of President Obama or defy voters who are overwhelmingly opposed to involving the United States in another unpredictable Middle East war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Democrats, torn over involving the United States in another unpredictable Middle East war, are emerging as a major barrier to President Obama’s plan to strike Syria.

articles.headline: Bezos Is a Hit in a Washington Post Newsroom Visit
articles.snippet: Jeffrey P. Bezos assured editors and reporters of his commitment to preserving quality journalism at the newspaper, which he is buying for $250 million.
articles.abstract: Jeffrey P. Bezos assured editors and reporters of his commitment to preserving quality journalism at the newspaper, which he is buying for $250 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey P. Bezos, Amazon’s founder and the prospective new owner of The Washington Post, assured newsroom employees on Wednesday that he was committed to preserving quality journalism, investing in news and making sure The Post adhered to his underlying philosophy about content: “Don’t be boring.”
articles.byline: By Christine Haughney and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: F.T.C. Says Webcam’s Flaw Put Users’ Lives on Display
articles.snippet: In a case that highlights the vulnerabilities of digitally connected devices like appliances and cars — the so-called Internet of Things — the F.T.C. censured a maker of video cameras.
articles.abstract: In a case that highlights the vulnerabilities of digitally connected devices like appliances and cars — the so-called Internet of Things — the F.T.C. censured a maker of video cameras.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The so-called Internet of Things — digitally connected devices like appliances, cars and medical equipment — promises to make life easier for consumers. But regulators are worried that some products may be magnets for hackers.

articles.headline: Brutality of Syrian Rebels Posing Dilemma in West
articles.snippet: Many Syrian rebels have adopted some of the chillingly ruthless tactics of the government, raising the prospect that a military strike could strengthen extremists.
articles.abstract: Many Syrian rebels have adopted some of the chillingly ruthless tactics of the government, raising the prospect that a military strike could strengthen extremists.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Syrian rebels posed casually, standing over their prisoners with firearms pointed down at the shirtless and terrified men.
